Award.AbstractNarration:
The Great Plains Combinatorics Conference 2018 is planned to be held at Kansas State University, Manhattan, KS, on the weekend of April 28-29, 2018. The conference covers various subfields of combinatorics, including algebraic combinatorics and graph theory. Combinatorics is an important area of mathematics. It is closely related to other areas of mathematics and has applications to other sciences, including computer science, biology, and physics.

The Great Plains Combinatorics Conferences is a regional conference series in combinatorics that has been held in 2014 and 2016 at the University of Kansas. Many research universities in the western Great Plains have small groups (often just one or two faculty members) working in combinatorics, and the low concentration of universities means that combinatorialists are somewhat geographically isolated from each other. Accordingly, the Great Plains Combinatorics Conference (GPCC) was started in 2014 to bring together combinatorialists from the region, modeled after other successful regional conferences such as CombinaTexas and KUMUNU. The meetings are held over a weekend, with most participants arriving on Friday evening. There are usually 4 plenary talks on Saturday, plus a graduate students poster session, and 3 plenary talks on Sunday.



This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Great Plains Combinatorics Conference is a regional conference in combinatorics. The first and the second conferences has been held in 2014 and 2016 at the University of Kansas.

Many research universities in the western Great Plains have small groups (often just one or two facultymembers) working in combinatorics, and the low concentration of universities means that combinatorialistsare somewhat geographically isolated from each other. In addition, combinatorics has a relatively youngdemographic, with many researchers at the level of Assistant or Associate Professor. Accordingly, the Great Plains Combinatorics Conference (GPCC) was started in 2014 to bring together combinatorialists from theregion, modeled after other successful regional conferences such as CombinaTexas and KUMUNU.

The third Great Plains Combinatorics Conference was held on April 28-29, 2018 at Kansas State Univeristy. The invited speakers were

Andrew Beveridge (Macalester College)

Federico Castillo (University of Kansas)

Nursel Erey (North Dakota State University)

Jia Huang (University of Nebraska at Kearney)

Laura Matusevich (University of Texas, A&M)

Xavier Perez-Gimenez (University of Nebraska at  Lincoln)

Katherine Perry (University of Denver)

Of these speakers, Andrew Beveridge and Laura Matusevich are tenured professors and Jia Huang and Xavier Perez-Giminez are tenure-track assistant professor; Federico Castillo, Katherine Perry, and Nursel Erey were postdoctoral researchers. A total of 43 participants attended, including 20 faculty members or postdocs and 23 graduate and undergraduate students. The poster session for graduate students attracted seven presenters. The website of the conference is available at

https://www.math.ksu.edu/events/conference/great plains combinatorics/2018/


Last Modified: 03/05/2020
Modified by: Mikhail Mazin
